awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Engineering a Community-Family Partnership: Developing a Program Aimed at Making and Design Practices in Home Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Families play a vital role in children's paths toward STEM careers yet little is knowns about how this influence works. This project addresses this knowledge gap by developing, implementing, and refining a program for integrating Making and engineering design practices into the home environments of families from under-resourced communities. The researchers hypothesize that an intervention focused on engaging underserved youth and their caregivers about ways to implement Making/engineering design practices in their home will enhance their awareness of and affinity for STEM careers relative to those who do not participate. The project has 3 specific aims. (1) Investigate features of the intervention that best support participation and implementation of Making/engineering design practices in home environments.  (2) Investigate changes in each youth's STEM identity in relation to engaging in Making/engineering design practices with caregivers in their home.  (3) Examine shifts in parental: (a) views of engineering, (b) support for their child's engagement in engineering design practices, and (c) beliefs about engineering as a viable degree/career option for their child.
 
The project is unique in that it takes a rare process look at how students and families engage in home-based STEM activities. It concurrently assesses families' readiness to support STEM career awareness and children's engagement in home-based STEM activities. The target audience is families with children in grades 3-6 enrolled in Title I schools in Bloomington, Indiana and Broome County, New York. Project partners include the Boys and Girls Clubs in these communities who assist with recruitment and with the delivery of the intervention, Family Making Nights. At home, families will document their design activities as they unfold. Stimulated recall with video and semi-structured interviews will help the research team understand families' thinking about what occurred during the activities. The use of a comparison group allows the team to compare the behaviors and outcomes associated with "trained" and "untrained" family supports. Grounded in social cognitive career theory and research on interest, the project's focus on identity development has potential to inform theories of social learning. As such, the project will advance the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program's efforts to better understand and promote practices that increase student motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was a collaboration between Binghamton University, State University of New York and Indiana University. As a research team, our long-term goal is to increase the number of individuals from historically social excluded groups entering and persisting in pathways to STEM careers. We were interested in an alternative approach to address this goal - inclusion of parents as key members in this process. Our objective was to develop a program for families with children in grades 3-6 to engage in activities similar to what engineers do, but in their home environments. Through this project, we developed 12 engineering-focused kits and a facilitation guide that highlights the ins and outs of the program (e.g., recruitment approaches, communication with parents) and provides additional resources (e.g., online show-and-tell games). These can be accessed at https://athomeengineers.com/. We created our engineering kits using the following five design principles: (1) leverage familiar environments and materials such as cardboard boxes, cotton balls, and yarn; (2) broaden the understanding of engineers and the process of engineering; (3) support the development of knowledge and skills of both adults and children through activities that have multiple approaches; (4) balance - frustration/failure with iteration and creativity with procedures; and (5) position parents as engineering facilitators and co-learners. We are expanding our work to develop kits for families with a child in pre-kindergarten to grade 1 and for homeschool families due to the positive outcomes from this project (described below).

Impact on Children

For children in our project, our research showed the multiple ways they were positively developing their identities as engineers. For example, many children expressed how their actions and behaviors were similar to actions and behaviors of engineers. The most common way they expressed doing engineering was through their experiences with failures. Throughout the program, children became more comfortable with failures and were able to develop creative ways to overcome challenges. Furthermore, engagement in this project heightened some children?s interest in engineering as a career or a hobby. As stated by Annie, a sixth-grade child, ?I could see myself being an engineer and designing things that would help people or something.? Lastly, children were afforded the opportunity to engage in math and science concepts and practices through the engineering kits.

Impact on Parents

Our results also showed that parents play a unique role as educators because they know their child(ren)?s prior experiences (e.g., trip to Disney Land), family history, frustration points, and fine motor skills. Parents shared how the program shifted their interactions with their child(ren),including being more detailed and understandable when explaining how things work, reconsidering the types of questions asked, and asking their child(ren) for help when repairing something. Some parents even positioned their children as partners, or even lead engineers, in solving problems and challenges together.

In this project, parents were able to support their children as engineers, but also facilitate and discuss math and science concepts with their child(ren) within the completion of the engineering kits. As one example, parents used purposeful questioning, blended their ideas with their child, and shared experiences supporting children?s creative thinking and innovation when finding solutions to an engineering problem. As another example, parents acknowledged their children?s frustrations and failure moments, and chose to model how to work through it or suggest ways to move beyond frustrations and failures. We also observed parents teaching their child(ren) everyday concepts and ideas such as why there are so many stray animals in the U.S. or why we do not get near water during a lightening storm.

Through the project, parents also gained new insights into their child(ren)?s development. Many parents described how their child(ren) developed new processes and modeled the thinking and perseverance of engineers. Parents also noted the development of an inquisitive mindset regarding how their child(ren) used and transformed materials and objects in their home and community environments.

Conclusion

We conclude with this quote from a parent. ?I think this project is really good for the whole family. We had to sit down together and set up the time, and then create some ideas and work together to find materials.? This project has allowed families an opportunity to work together in a field that is less prevalent in school settings - engineering. There was also flexibility in when, where, and how families engaged with the kits. Broadly, the collective results from this project point to the home environment as a site to potentially diminish exclusionary and inequitable access to out-of-school learning environments such as travel and cost. Further, children?s engagement in the program has the potential to increase their likelihood of entering and persisting in pathways to STEM careers.
